subject: Relationships
title: Trauma Bonding: When Pain Feels Like Love
description: A quick, practical guide to Trauma Bonding: When Pain Feels Like Love.

hook.text: She knows he's destroying her. She still loves him more than anyone. That's not weakness ‚Äî it's chemistry.

buildup.text: Trauma bonding occurs when cycles of abuse and affection create intense neurochemical attachment.

discovery.text: The bond uses the same brain pathways as substance addiction: dopamine surges during good times, cortisol during bad.

twist.text: Telling someone to 'just leave' is like telling an addict to 'just stop.' The bond is physiological, not rational.

climax.text: Trauma bonds feel like the deepest love you've ever known. That intensity isn't a sign of love ‚Äî it's a sign of danger.

punchline.text: Trauma bonds feel like deep love. The intensity is a warning, not a gift.

quiz.question: What causes trauma bonding?
options: Cycles of abuse and affection creating neurochemical attachment
